rsbNotes.title: Job 3–27
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–27:23 In three cycles of speeches, the writer explores human perspectives on Job’s suffering.

rsbNotes.title: Job 20
rsbNotes.text: 20:1–29 Ch. 20 is another eloquent statement of the fate of the wicked. In it, Zophar expresses the truth of the moral governance of the world by God, but fails to make a correct application of it.

rsbNotes.title: Job 20:2
rsbNotes.text: 20:2 my haste within me. Job’s closing words in 19:28, 29 have not been lost on Zophar.

rsbNotes.title: Job 20:29
rsbNotes.text: 20:29 This is the wicked man’s portion from God. What Zophar teaches will ultimately come to pass, but sadly, he has no word to say about God’s mercy. Even in his earlier speech in 11:13–20, where he called on Job to change his ways, there is no mention of mercy. People get God’s blessing, according to Zophar, only by earning it.

rsbNotes.title: Job 21
rsbNotes.text: 21:1–34 Job closes this second cycle with a firm rejection of the friends’ arguments that the wicked always suffer. Note how he alludes to their very words. Cf. 20:11 with 21:7; 8:19 with 21:8; 18:5 with 21:17; 5:4 and 20:10 with 21:19; 20:5–7 with 21:28–30.

rsbNotes.title: Job 21:5
rsbNotes.text: 21:5 Look at me and be appalled, and lay your hand over your mouth. If they had any compassion, Job thinks that they would stop accusing him and lying about him.

rsbNotes.title: Job 21:7
rsbNotes.text: 21:7 Why do the wicked live. Job admits that he is perplexed. He has no answer. The counselors assumed they knew exactly what was going on (cf. John 9:41).

rsbNotes.title: Job 21:22
rsbNotes.text: 21:22 Will any teach God knowledge. Job’s high view of God only makes his problem more perplexing.

rsbNotes.title: Job 22
rsbNotes.text: 22:1–30 Eliphaz begins the third cycle of speeches (22:1–26:14) listing Job’s sins and calling on him to repent.

rsbNotes.title: Job 22:2–3
rsbNotes.text: 22:2, 3 Eliphaz reacts to Job’s statement that God allows wickedness to go unpunished, and he also says that human uprightness adds nothing to Him.

rsbNotes.title: Job 22:3
rsbNotes.text: 22:3 The sense may be, “Would it please God if you were vindicated?”

rsbNotes.title: Job 22:5
rsbNotes.text: 22:5 Eliphaz reached the conclusion Zophar and Bildad had already expressed—that Job’s sins are endless.

rsbNotes.title: Job 22:6–11
rsbNotes.text: 22:6–11 Here is a direct personal attack on Job for specific sins, especially social sins against the poor and widows. Later Job will emphasize his social righteousness (chs. 29; 31).

rsbNotes.title: Job 22:12–14
rsbNotes.text: 22:12–14 Eliphaz attacks Job’s complaint that God is absent (13:24). It is not unnatural for Job, in the midst of suffering, to complain that God is either too observant and intrusive to leave him alone (7:17–19; 10:8; 16:9), or too far away.
